ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Duck on a Bike. We learned about Duck’s adventures as he learned how to ride a bike. We also learned about words with the same beginning sounds.

In this activity, we will look at pictures of different objects. We will identify the objects, and say the beginning sound we hear. Then we will sort the cards with the beginning sounds into two groups:

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Bb: For words that start with the /b/.
Cc: For words that start with the /c/.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach/Model Give children examples of words that have the same beginning sounds, for example, bag and book or cow and color.
Ask Show one picture card and ask children the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge and support where needed.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to sort in the “Bb” or “Cc” column.
Extend Use the last question to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Beginning Sounds Remind children about all of the words that have the same beginning sounds. The ones in the story: wobbled, wild, wandered, and the ones they learned today, cat and cake, and bike and bus. Ask children to think of other examples by looking around the classroom.
Ask children to identify the object in the picture, stressing the beginning sound of the word. For children who have a hard time pronouncing the word, invite them to say the word after you.
Have children think of other words that have the same beginning sounds as the picture cards. Challenge children by asking them if they could write the letters on a piece of paper.

Be aware that some children whose first language is Spanish may pronounce the letters Bb and Vv alike. Take extra time, as needed, to review the sounds those letters make in English, both in isolation and in the context of a picture word. Challenge children to name the object in the picture in their home language.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sounds.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65574-2. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we learned that it’s good to talk about our feelings. We learned that understanding how we feel can help us feel better. For example, if we know that we’re angry or sad, we can figure out a way to solve our own problem.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit Vocabulary We learned the word behavior. This word will help us understand today’s activity. Use the behavior Vocabulary Card to revisit the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures and try to match the person’s behavior you see in the picture to how they are feeling. Then we’ll talk about things the person might do to feel better.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk: Let’s look at this first card. What do we see? Is this child feeling happy or sad? How can you tell?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the next picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Feelings Invite children to describe their behavior when they are hungry, angry, surprised, tired, sad, or scared. Encourage children to think about ways that they could make themselves feel better when they are sad, angry, or tired.

Make sure that children understand each feeling by asking them if they have ever felt each feeling. To check their understanding, ask children to give examples of feeling cranky, lonely, tired, and angry.

Encourage children to participate in peer-to-peer conversations about feeling like the person in the picture. Each child will take two turns in the conversation. Remind children that while one person is talking, the other is listening.

Invite volunteers to teach the class how to say I am happy and I am sad in their home language. Children will excel more in English if they feel that, by learning English, their ability to communicate in their home language is not being threatened. You can create an atmosphere in the classroom where knowing another language is considered a valuable skill.

Help children recognize the early-warning signs of a negative feeling. Your understanding and concern in the early stages of an emotional outburst can go a long way to reduce the escalation of tension. Help children make the connection between their feelings and their behaviors.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65574-2. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Duck on a Bike. We learned that Duck found a bike a boy had parked and decided to ride it. He pedaled and pedaled until he learned how to ride the bike.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit Vocabulary We learned the words parked and pedaled. They are both past tense words. Review what past tense means. Use the parked and pedaled Vocabulary Cards to revisit the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at pictures that show people doing different actions. We will talk about what they are doing in the picture and then describe the activity as if they did the action yesterday.
For example, I can say, “I like to walk up the stairs. Yesterday, I walked up the stairs.” The word walked is the past tense of the word walk because it happened already.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the next picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About the Past Tense Invite children to talk about something they did today, and then talk about something they did yesterday. Encourage children to use past tense verbs as they describe what they did.
For developmentally challenged children, say the correct answer to the questions on the back of the cards and have the children repeat the answers after you. Make sure to stress the past tense words.

Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about other past tense verbs they can think of. If children are unable to think of examples, provide actions they may have done today in class or at home.

Multilingual learners (like babies acquiring their first language) learn best through oral language experiences. Children who are immersed in rich language through read-aloud books and teacher and parent modeling will naturally learn to use the correct forms of verbs. There are some verb past tenses that even adults have to look up from time to time, but the most common past tenses will come naturally to children who are exposed to them on a regular basis.

In this activity, preview the first card with children, making sure that children understand that they must respond in a complete sentence. Let children know that if they need help you will say the answer, and they will repeat it. Make the activity more engaging by asking children to repeat the sentence in a loud voice and then a soft voice.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65574-2. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we learned about what we need to do to be healthy. We talked about eating healthy foods and exercising.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different foods and we will sort the picture cards into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Healthy foods—Foods that are good for you. You can eat these all the time.
Unhealthy foods—Foods that are not good for you. You shouldn’t eat them all the time.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s look at this first card. What do we see? Are apples healthy or unhealthy?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the next picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Have children sort each picture card into “Healthy Foods” and “Unhealthy Foods” categories.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Talk About Healthy and Unhealthy Foods
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s see how many healthy foods we can name. Now let’s see how many unhealthy foods we can name.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About Eating Healthy Discuss with children moderation, explaining that it’s okay to have a cookie, a piece of candy, a sugary drink, or fried foods, but they should limit the amount of unhealthy foods they eat each day.
Review what is pictured on each picture card before you begin. Have children practice saying the words healthy and unhealthy.
Discuss which ways of cooking foods are healthy and unhealthy. Show children pictures of foods that are baked, steamed, and fried.

Food is often tied to cultural identity, so you want to be careful not to criticize a particular food or method of food preparation that is important and familiar to your children. Rather, help children recognize foods that are high in sugar and unhealthy fats, and emphasize moderation. What is important is that children learn to make healthy food choices and recognize that they can limit unhealthy foods, including their daily intake of sugar and unhealthy fats.

Tell children that exercise is also an important part of being healthy. Explain that running and jumping are good for their hearts. Have children run and jump in place. Ask children why they need to make sure that they don’t spend all of their time watching television or playing games on the computer or on a tablet.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65574-2. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
